thread.title: Meet the Spurs: A look at the 2015-16 roster

author: Dan McCarney
title: Meet the Spurs: A look at the 2015-16 roster

The Heat defeated the Spurs 97-94. The Heat defeated the Spurs 97-94. Photo: Wilfredo Lee /Associated Press Image 17 of 17 Meet the Spurs: A look at the 2015-16 roster 1 / 17 Back to Gallery LaMarcus Aldridge
Position: Forward
Experience: 10th season
Height, weight: 6-11, 240
2014-15 (with Portland): 23.4 ppg, 10.2 rpg, 22.8 PER, plus 5.7 net rating
Nickname: L.A.
Best case: Hits the ground running with his new team and fits perfectly into its motion offense.
Worst case: Chafes at having to take fewer shots than he got as the focal point in Portland.
Bet you didn’t know: Aldridge’s shoe collection is so massive he’s building a separate structure to house it behind his mansion in Dallas .
Kyle Anderson
Position: Forward
Experience: 2nd season
Height, weight: 6-9, 220
2014-15: 2.2 ppg, 2.2 rpg, 8.2 PER, minus 4.8 net rating
Nickname: Slo Mo
Best case: Shows enough improvement to crack what should be another deep Spurs rotation.
Worst case: Progress stagnates after his MVP performance at the Las Vegas Summer League.
Bet you didn’t know: Went 93-1 during his high school career, including 65-0 with a pair of New Jersey state championships in his junior and senior seasons.
Matt Bonner
Position: Forward
Experience: 12th season
Height, weight: 6-10, 240
2014-15: 3.7 ppg, 36.5 3PT%, 10.1 PER, plus 1.1 net rating
Nickname: The Red Mamba
Best case: Bonner’s 3-point percentage climbs back above 40.0, giving the Spurs quality situational shooting.
Worst case: Bonner is a non-factor in what will likely be his last season with the Spurs.
Bet you didn’t know: Bonner collects vinyl records, sports trading cards and bobblehead dolls, and is a partner in the New Hampshire-based collectors website Gemr.
Boris Diaw
Position: Forward
Experience: 7th season
Height, weight: 6-8, 250
2014-15: 8.7 ppg, 4.3 rpg, 2.9 apg, 12.7 PER, plus 6.7 net rating
Nickname: Bobo
Best case: Rediscovers shooting touch that abandoned him last season after the two most efficient years of his career.
Worst case: Diaw’s accuracy doesn’t recover as age — he’ll be 34 in April — creeps up on him.
Bet you didn’t know: Released a children’s book this summer in conjunction with National Geographic titled “Hoops to Hippos!: True Stories of a Basketball Star on Safari .”
Tim Duncan
Position: Center/forward
Experience: 19th season
Height, weight: 6-11, 240
2014-15: 13.9 ppg, 9.1 rpg, 2.0 bpg, 22.6 PER, plus 7.0 net rating
Nickname: The Big Fundamental
Best case: Continues to thumb his nose at Father Time, contending for his 16th All-Star berth.
Worst case: Age finally catches up to the Spurs’ longtime cornerstone, who will turn 40 next April.
Bet you didn’t know: The first shot of Duncan’s career, a left-handed jump hook, was blocked by Greg Ostertag . Duncan recovered nicely.
Rasual Butler
Position: Forward
Experience: 13th season
Height, weight: 6-7, 215
2014-15: 7.7 ppg in 75 games in reserve role with Washington, right at his career norm of 7.8. Shot 42.2 percent from the field (38.7 from 3-ponit range) and 2.6 rebounds in 20.1 minutes.
Nickname: Sual Bop, but should be “oft-traveled” as Spurs would be his ninth NBA team.
Best case: Gives the Spurs another option off the bench from 3-point range.
Worst case: Age catches up with him and his long-distance accuracy diminishes.
Bet you didn’t know: He is close friends with former NBA player Lamar Odom .
Manu Ginobili
Position: Guard
Experience: 14th season
Height, weight: 6-6, 210
2014-15: 10.5 ppg, 4.2 apg, 16.2 PER, plus 9.6 net rating
Nickname: El Contusion
Best case: Bounces back from an inconsistent year to give the Spurs one last quality season.
Worst case: Age further erodes Ginobili’s skills as he ends his illustrious career in forgettable fashion.
Bet you didn’t know: Ginobili was asleep when the Spurs took him with the 57th pick in the 1999 draft. His reaction upon hearing the news the following day? “You’re crazy.”
Danny Green
Position: Guard
Experience: 7th season
Height, weight: 6-6, 210
2014-15: 11.7 ppg, 41.8 3PT%, 16.5 PER, plus 9.9 net rating
Nickname: Icy Hot
Best case: Maintains dead-eye stroke from 3-point range while expanding his offensive game.
Worst case: Green’s fat new contract goes to his head.
Bet you didn’t know: Green is second cousins with journeyman guard Gerald Green , the 2007 NBA slam dunk champion.
Kawhi Leonard
Position: Forward
Experience: Fifth season
Height, weight: 6-7, 220
2014-15: 16.5 ppg, 7.2 rpg, 2.3 spg, 22.0 PER, plus 12.0 net rating
Nickname: The Klaw
Best case: Builds off fantastic finish to 2014-15 to earn first All-Star nod.
Worst case: Progress stagnates as he fails to take a permanent step up among the NBA’s elite.
Bet you didn’t know: At 11.25 inches from thumb to pinkie, Leonard’s hands are 52 percent larger than the average male.
Boban Marjanovic
Position: Center
Experience: 1st season
Height, weight: 7-3, 290
2014-15 (with Red Star Belgrade ): 16.6 ppg, 10.7 rpg, 25.7 PER
Nickname: The Bobinator
Best case: Steps in for the departed Aron Baynes and provides much-needed backup minutes at center.
Worst case: Marjanovic’s defense, a major weakness in Europe, limits his utility.
Bet you didn’t know: Marjanovic’s wingspan (7-8) and standing reach (9-7) are tied for third and sixth among all measured draft prospects over the past 15 years.
Ray McCallum
Position: Guard
Experience: 3rd season
Height, weight: 6-3, 190
2014-15 (with Sacramento): 7.4 ppg, 2.8 apg, 12.5 PER, minus 8.9 net rating
Best case: Blossoms as a legitimate backup to Parker.
Worst case: Fails to fill Cory Joseph ’s shoes, leaving the Spurs dangerously thin at point guard.
Bet you didn’t know: Despite being a McDonald’s All-American, McCallum eschewed bigger offers to play for his father, Ray McCallum Sr., at the University of Detroit .
Patty Mills
Position: Guard
Experience: 7th season
Height, weight: 6-0, 185
2014-15: 6.9 ppg, 34.1 3PT%, 13.0 PER, plus 9.0 net rating
Best case: Additional rehab on his surgically repaired shooting shoulder over the summer helps him regain his firecracker form from 2013-14.
Worst case: Mills fails to bounce all the way back to that career peak even at full health.
Bet you didn’t know: Mills was named “Best and Fairest” — translated: MVP — at the 2004 Australian Rules Football under-15 national championships.
Tony Parker
Position: Guard
Experience: 15th season
Height, weight: 6-2, 180
2014-15: 14.4 ppg, 4.9 apg, 42.7 3PT%, 15.9 PER, plus 5.4 net rating
Best case: Snaps two-year decline to recapture his All-Star form.
Worst case: Said decline continues as Parker’s impact dips for a third straight season.
Bet you didn’t know: Parker reached 700 career victories faster than any other player in NBA history, beating Scottie Pippen by seven games at 973. (Tim Duncan got there in 991.)
Jonathon Simmons
Position: Forward
Experience: 1st season
Height, weight: 6-6, 195
2014-15 (with Austin, D-League): 15.2 ppg, 4.3 rpg, 3.7 apg, 13.7 PER, minus 3.0 net rating
Best case: Capable of providing spot minutes as a true backup to Kawhi Leonard, something the Spurs have lacked.
Worst case: Fails to prove he’s an NBA player.
Bet you didn’t know: Simmons averaged 36.5 points in 16 games with the Sugar Land Legends of the defunct American Basketball League after going undrafted in 2012.
David West
Position: Forward
Experience: 13th season
Height, weight: 6-9, 240
2014-15 (with Indiana): 11.7 ppg, 6.8 rpg, 3.4 apg, 16.0 PER, plus 0.1 net rating
Nickname: D West
Best case: West fleshes out the Spurs’ depth with a welcome dose of experience and toughness.
Worst case: At 35, West’s scoring production and efficiency decline for a third straight season.
Bet you didn’t know: West is an avid reader who is particularly interested in black history, psychology and philosophy. “The more information I get,” he said, “the better.”
Reggie Williams
Position: Forward
Experience: 7th season
Height, weight: 6-6, 210
2014-15: 1.9 ppg, 0.9 rpg, 10.5 PER, minus 15.0 net rating
Best case: Journeyman sticks for the full season, edges Simmons for backup role as Leonard’s caddie.
Worst case: Bested by Fredette in training camp for 15th and final roster spot.
Bet you didn’t know: Williams has played for 11 different teams since turning pro.
Spurs roster as of Oct. 21.
